This game is a masterpiece. First of all, the gameplay is extremely good. The puzzles are entertaining and they require smart solutions. The graphics are very good taking into consideration that the game was released in in 2007. But it definitely does not look like a 2007 game, it is way better. Also, the jokes and the irony of the robot that speaks to you are quite good. The story is ok, but it could have been better. Also, the game is a little too short. In conclusion, the game is very enjoyable and is definitely worth its money.
fantastic game, with intuitive game play and an enjoyable story line. Can't wait to play portal 2.

SPOILERS AHEAD




Portal is one of Valve's shortest single player games that they've made. It can be finished in less than two hours by someone who knows what they're doing. Despite this, the game has managed to be one of the most influential games of all time, thanks to its innovative, simple, and fun gameplay. The idea of teleporting from one place to another in the way the game did, along with the mechanics possible with them, hadn't ever been seen before until Portal. You wake up out of your bed, not knowing anything about what's going on. As you try and put as many things as you can into the toilet, an AI named GLaDOS starts to talk to you. You then procceed to begin completing various puzzles. As you progress, the puzzles get more complicated and add new mechanics to them. The way it's done is excellent as it eases players into the game and what's possible with it. It's a very accessible game to play. Throughout the game, a feeling and environment of loneliness is felt as you see areas where people would normally watch you in be empty. The amazing ambiance music sets in that feeling and environment very well. There's no one but you and an AI that doesn't seem to be alright. As you continue with the game, your suspicion regarding GLaDOS' true nature grows, as the chambers become more and more dangerous. These suspicions are confirmed when you find an area with scribbles written by someone who may not be at the facility anymore. They hint at GLaDOS' true intentions at the end of the experiment. When you finish all 19 chambers, you're rewarded with a fire pit, that you escape from. At that intense moment, everything about GLaDOS' true nature gets revealed. The music that plays as you get closer to the pit is as intense as the moment and it's brilliant. You then go and begin trying to escape the facility while GLaDOS discourages you and tries to emotionally manipulate you into thinking that you've hurt her feelings. The enviroments throughout the escape sequence changes from the mostly white chambers to rusted metal areas, showing you that you've truly gone into the behind the scenes of the enrichment center. You make your way to GLaDOS' chamber and fight her, destroying her and making it out of the facility... until you get dragged back in.

Portal and its sequel are must plays for anyone who plays video games. They are brilliant masterpieces that deserve to be among the best games ever made.

I can't recommend this. It's a puzzle game where all puzzles are solved with the game's only weapon/item: The Portal Gun. All the environments use the same textures, and the look of the game gets boring very soon because of the lack of visual variety. There are no enemies or other activities besides the puzzle solving. I just wanted the game to end at all times, almost. I think this should be a freeware game, or at least extremely cheap taking account the game only lasts 2-3 hours.
